frameDefinitions: A Protagonist has (or does not have) a Weapon.
An Item becomes filled with a Substance as a result of movement of liquid into visible or invisible interstices in the Item.
An Agent, by virtue of strength or forcefulness, controls, rules, or strongly influences some Patient in some Situation.
An Agent causes a Patient to be wet with a Liquid.

This frame involves a static (primarily spatial) relationship between a Location and a Theme, in which the Theme is located in many or all subregions of the Location, and is thus construable as covering it.
An Ingestor consumes food or drink (Ingestibles), which entails putting the Ingestibles in the mouth for delivery to the digestive system.
frameExamples: Apparently, the suspect is <t>armed</t> with a shotgun.
Paper and board <t>absorb</t> moisture in the winter.
The fireballing righthander looked poised to <t>dominate</t> the Yankees yet again, striking out seven straight batters during one stretch
listRoleDefinitions: The destructive device that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> has with them.
The individual that possesses a <fen>Weapon</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> carries a <fen>Weapon</fen>.
The location where a <fen>Protagonist</fen> carries a <fen>Weapon</fen>.
The <fen>Item</fen> is the absorbant friendly thing that takes in the <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Substance</fen> is the material that is taken in by the <fen>Item</fen>.
When the <fen>Item</fen> takes in <fen>Substance</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Item</fen> takes in <fen>Substance</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> controls the Patient by being forceful and possibly aggressive.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is trying to gain control of a situation, but ends up being subject to the control and influence of the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The time when the domination takes place.
The place where the domination occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is a volitional animate being who causes the <fen>Patient</fen> to become wet.
The <fen>Liquid</fen> is a fluid or gas that permeates or covers the <fen>Patient</fen>.  It most frequently occurs in a PP Complement headed by with.
The <fen>Patient</fen> takes up the <fen>Liquid</fen> through its pores or has the <fen>Liquid</fen> covering its surface.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces the state of wetness.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> wets the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> wets the <fen>Patient</fen>.

The <fen>Theme</fen> in this frame is the object which is described as standing in some spatial relation to a particular <fen>Location</fen>.  <fen>Theme</fen> typically occurs as the External Argument or, with passives, as a PP Complement headed by 'with' or 'by'.
<fen>Location</fen> is the entity or area with respect to which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s spatial arrangement is described.  This frame element generally occurs as an NP Object.
The time at which the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Ingestor</fen> is the person eating or drinking.
The <fen>Ingestibles</fen> are the entities that are being consumed by the <fen>Ingestor</fen>.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: Their role models might have dominated women <fex>in the past</fex>; they may not have understood the concept of equality.
Women tend to dominatemen <fex>at home and at Church</fex>.
<fex>Hannah</fex> drenched the cat with anti-flea ointment.
